description: Borrowed from French cirque (“circular arena; cirque”), from Latin circus (“circle, ring”), from Ancient Greek κίρκος (kírkos, “circle, ring; racecourse, circus”), possibly ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker- (“to bend; to turn”). Doublet of circus.

entries.meaning: (geology) A curved depression in a mountainside with steep walls, forming the end of a valley.
(dated or literary) Something in the shape of a circle or ring, such as a Roman circus.
